content: The "Alcohol Tax Equalization Act of 1997" may increase excise taxes on wine and beer to match taxes on distilled spirits. The Alcohol Tax Equalization Act of 1997 raises taxes on wines and beers based on alcohol content. Wines with up to 14% alcohol are taxed at $2.97, wines with 14-21% alcohol at $4.86, and wines with 21-24% alcohol at $6.08. For beer, the tax rate is increased from $18 to $37.67. The amendments will take effect on January 1, 1998, and floor stock taxes will be imposed on articles held for sale before that date. Definitions for terms used in the act are provided, including the meanings of "person" and "Secretary." SEC. 3. INDEXATION OF TAX RATES APPLICABLE TO ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section for indexation of rates for alcoholic beverages. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces indexation of tax rates for alcoholic beverages, with tax rates being increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes technical and clerical amendments related to tax rates for alcoholic beverages. SEC. 9512. SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION TRUST FUND. The Substance Abuse Prevention Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by additional taxes under the Alcohol Tax Equalization Act of 1997. Amounts in the Trust Fund can be appropriated to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration. The Substance Abuse Prevention Trust Fund is established to fund alcohol abuse prevention programs by the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
